node.title: How this Victorian queer community is finding beauty and identity through clothing swap
node.alt: a sign that reads "life is party, dress like it" next to some beads
node.description: When we are getting ready in the morning, most of us rummage through the wardrobe trying to pick out what we're going to wear that day.Â But for some people, it's not that simple.
node.content:
["When we are getting ready in the morning, most of us rummage through the wardrobe\u00a0trying to pick out what we're going to wear that day.\u00a0", "And it's important because it makes us feel good about ourselves.", "But for some people, it's not that simple. Those who identify as queer can often be confronted with a wardrobe that does not represent them or how they want others\u00a0to see\u00a0them.", "It's this that led Zara Jones to create a Trans and Gender Diverse Clothing Swap in Bendigo, in Central Victoria, where people \u2014 whether they are male, female or non-binary \u2014 can try on new clothes and experiment with a new look without feeling judged.", "\"When I came out and started transitioning socially, I had a whole wardrobe that no longer affirmed my gender,\" she said.", "\"I started going to op-shops to find things to replace my wardrobe with, but it became very expensive and there were times where I just felt very uncomfortable.", "", "
Zara Jones created the\u00a0Trans and Gender Diverse Clothing Swap in Bendigo after finding it hard to find clothes while\u00a0transitioning.(ABC Central Victoria: Tyrone Dalton)
", "\"I got looks from the staff members as I was early in my transition and not being seen as female, yet I was looking at female clothes and so there was a lot of judgement.", "", "
The clothing swap helps people find all the necessary clothing needed to affirm their new identity.(ABC Central Victoria: Tyrone Dalton)
", "Alex\u00a0used the clothing swap when he was transitioning to find more masculine clothing, but said he also found people he could connect with.", "", "
Alex says he began using the clothing swap when transitioning to find more masculine clothing.(ABC Central Victoria: Tyrone Dalton)
", "\"I felt really isolated. But I first thought that I was the only trans person locally, as the only one in Bendigo. So it was really hard,\" he said.", "\"And so coming to the clothing swap and seeing how many of us there are, I really felt like I had a community here.", "\"Just being out in public can be terrifying, especially if people can kind of tell you're trans. So taking that first step can be really scary but really amazing.\"", "The weekend marked 40 years since the decriminalisation of sex between men in Victoria and Pride events were held across the state in support of the LGBTQIA+ community.", "ABC Central Victoria is a media partner of Bendigo Pride and at the weekend the gardens beside the town came alive as the region's LGBTQIA+ community and their allies came together to enjoy a pop-up festival.", "The Victorian Commissioner for LGBTQIA+ Communities, Todd Fernando, said some communities in regional Victoria had to do more to support their gender diverse members.", "", "
The Victorian Commissioner for LGBTQIA+ Communities, Todd Fernando.(ABC Central Victoria: Tyrone Dalton)
", "He said it was the small things that could make a big difference.", "\"Younger generations really do look up to allies as role models and the more allies that we have the more chances we have that young LGBTQI+ people can grow up in a safe and inclusive environment where coming out might be a distant past thing.", "\"When we silence and erase queer people or trans and gender diverse people from history, we're really erasing the present as well because we're not allowing those communities to really connect with who they are and who they can be and their identities.\"", "", "
John Richards and Chris Butler moved to Bendigo five years ago and created Bendigo Pride\u00a0to help unify the LGBTQI+ groups across the region.(ABC Central Victoria: Tyrone Dalton)
", "Bendigo Pride director John Richards moved to the regional city five years ago with his partner Chris Butler and said Bendigo had\u00a0come a long way in establishing itself as a place where LGBTQIA+ people can live without fear of being ostracised.", "\"I always say that thing of Bendigo pride. The pride works two ways. It's our pride in our community, but it's also our pride in living in Bendigo,\" he said.", "\"Talk to someone who grew up here 20 years ago, it's a different story. It's true that Bendigo has evolved.\"", "At the same-sex marriage plebiscite\u00a0in late 2017,\u00a068.7 per cent of the Bendigo electorate voted in support of changing Australia's marriage laws to allow same-sex couples to marry.", "\"We must find our own families and it can be very lonely and very isolating when you're, you know, a queer youth.\""]
